[[Dualtone Records|Dualtone]] | website = [http://www.deryldoddmusic.com] }} '''Deryl Dwaine Dodd''' (born April 12, 1964) is an American [[Texas Country|Texas country music]] artist. Originally a regular on the [[Texas]] club circuit, he moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], soon finding work as a lead guitar player, background vocalist and songwriter. After moving to Nashville in 1991 he played lead guitar for Tracy Lawrence and Martina McBride. By 1996, he was signed to a recording contract, releasing two albums for [[Columbia Records]] Nashville before a debilitating bout of [[viral encephalitis]] put his career on hiatus. Having recovered from his encephalitis in 2000, Dodd resumed his singing career, also touring with [[Tim McGraw]] and [[Faith Hill]]. He released a third album for Columbia in 2002, followed by two more albums for [[Dualtone Records]]. Overall, Dodd has released five studio albums and a live album, and has charted nine singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. His highest-charting single, "A Bitter End", peaked at No. 26 on the country charts and No. 88 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] in late 1998-early 1999. ==Biography== Deryl Dodd was raised in [[Dallas]], Texas, where he played [[American football|football]] from an early age.[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p71426/biography|pure_url=yes}} Deryl Dodd Biography], [[AllMusic]] After a career-ending injury, Dodd was persuaded to perform music in clubs throughout the state of Texas. In 1991, he moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], forming a band along with [[Brett Beavers]], now an established Nashville songwriter. Dodd later found work singing harmony vocals for [[Martina McBride]], [[Radney Foster]], and [[George Ducas (singer)|George Ducas]], in addition to playing in [[Tracy Lawrence]]'s road band, and co-writing a song on [[Tim McGraw]]'s ''[[All I Want (Tim McGraw album)|All I Want]]'' album.{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1492004/20041006/dodd_deryl.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930050249/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1492004/20041006/dodd_deryl.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 30, 2007 |title=How Deryl Dodd Got to Texas |accessdate=July 13, 2007 |website=Cmt.com }} Dodd signed to [[Columbia Records]] in 1996 as a solo act. His first album, ''One Ride in Vegas'', was released that year, producing a Top 40 hit on the U.S. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country music charts in the [[Tom T. Hall]]-penned "That's How I Got to Memphis".{{cite magazine|last=Price|first=Deborah Evans|date=October 2, 1998|title=Columbia's Dodd Steps into Spotlight|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|pages=44|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JQoEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22how+i+got+to+memphis&pg=PA44}} ''One Ride in Vegas'' was followed by an [[eponymous]] album in 1998. In 1999, Dodd was nominated for [[Academy of Country Music Award for New Male Artist of the Year|Top New Male Vocalist of the Year]] by the [[Academy of Country Music Awards]].{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1475759/20030805/dodd_deryl.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930050052/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1475759/20030805/dodd_deryl.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 30, 2007 |title=Dodd Recovers After Health Battle |accessdate=July 13, 2007 |website=Cmt.com}} His second album, after being delayed due to its initial lead single underperforming at radio,{{cite magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LgoEAAAAMBAJ&q=%22deryl+dodd%22+%22time+on+my+hands%22&pg=RA1-PA84|title=Reviews|date=December 5, 1998|magazine=Billboard|accessdate=January 2, 2018}} also produced his biggest chart hit to date in "A Bitter End", which peaked at No. 26 on the country charts. In 1999, Dodd was diagnosed with viral encephalitis, forcing him to temporarily halt his career.{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1474949/20030729/dodd_deryl.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930044036/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1474949/20030729/dodd_deryl.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 30, 2007 |title=Dodd Back On Track |accessdate=July 13, 2007 |website=Cmt.com}} He remained bedridden for six months, and then went through eighteen months of rehabilitation (which included re-learning how to play guitar). Once he had fully recovered, he attended several writers' nights in Nashville, and was later signed as an opening act on Tim McGraw and [[Faith Hill]]'s Soul2Soul tour. Dodd's third and final album for Columbia, ''Pearl Snaps'', was released in 2002. Later, he recorded ''Live at Billy Bob's Texas'', before switching to [[Dualtone Records]] in 2004 to release ''Stronger Proof'' (2004) and ''Full Circle'' (2006). In 2009, Dodd released a cover of "[[Together Again (Buck Owens song)|Together Again]]", originally a hit for [[Buck Owens]].{{cite web|url=http://www.engine145.com/deryl-dodd-together-again/|title=Deryl Dodd – "Together Again"|last=Justus|first=Karlie|date=August 6, 2009|work=Engine 145|accessdate=August 6, 2009|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218105954/http://www.engine145.com/deryl-dodd-together-again/|archivedate=December 18, 2014}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:14em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Album details ! colspan="2"| Peak chart
